headline: The Original Fantasy Fudge
description: The original fantasy fudge recipe from the back of the marshmallow cream jar. This big-batch fudge recipe can be made on the stovetop or in the microwave.

video.description: This fluffy and decadent fudge is everything and more!
video.name: The Original Fantasy Fudge

name: The Original Fantasy Fudge

recipeInstructions.text: Mix sugar, margarine, and evaporated milk in a large, heavy saucepan over medium heat, stirring to dissolve sugar. Bring mixture to a full boil and cook for 5 minutes, stirring constantly.
Remove from the heat and add chocolate chips; stir until chocolate chips are melted and mixture is thoroughly combined. Stir in marshmallow cream until incorporated. Mix in walnuts and vanilla.
Transfer fudge to the prepared pan and use an offset spatula to spread out and flatten. Let cool for at least 1 hour before cutting into squares.

review.reviewBody: I have used this recipe for over 50 years and I have always used butter and never had an issue. I use a hand mixer when adding chocolate, marshmallow and vanilla. I do double batches and boil about 8 minutes. I've never had anything but compliments and it's won a few contests.
this is a good fudge just follow the recipe you can't miss delish

I have been making this recipe for years, but I always use a candy thermometer. Bring to a boil from medium heat to reduce chances of burning the sugar. Bring sugar to the point just before soft ball stage (237-239 degrees F). I use actual chocolate instead of chips, just a preference. To prevent the fats from separating I let the chocolate/ marshmallow mixture cool to 120 degrees F before stirring in the vanilla and nuts. Otherwise my chocolate wants to seize up and all the fat from the milk and butter separates out and it looks like chocolate with butter poured on top. This can be fixed by putting in the stand mixer with the paddle attachment and beating until the fats incorporate again.
I love this recipe. I've been using it for years. The one thing that I changed was the instead of using all white sugar, I used half white and half brown sugar. It makes it much creamier.

My family and I absolutely love this recipe. I have been making it for years and it's always a big hit with friends and family. Though I usually make peanut butter fudge by substituting a 1 1/4c peanut butter for the chocolate. I have also always made it in the microwave. Fast, easy and simple. It can be a bit messy though but still fun to make and delicious to eat.

My Dad made this fudge for 40+ years. After he passed away none of us could get it to come out right. I finally realized the issue. We kept using BUTTER! I went to the store and picked up some margarine and it came out perfect. I can't believe we all kept skipping past that key word.
This is a family favorite. However, I think the original boil time of 4 minutes is more accurate. 5 minutes makes for a dry fudge and to me that is not a good fudge.

Thus fudge is absolutely amazing and perfect!!! It's not for the type of people who do things slowly lol as it requires serious stirring!!! But if you have any know how of making candy you will do great and it won't scorch! BEST FUDGE EVER!!!

This was my grandma fudge recipe. I could never find the original fantasy fudge and she passed away 4 years ago so tasting this took me back home to better times. Thank You! I didn’t Change anything and wouldn’t.

I have used this recipe for many years. I make a milk chocolate, raspberry pecan fudge that is always the hit of any Christmas party. My peanut butter pecan fudge is also a big hit. I use a little bit of almond extract in both and it adds some extra flavoring.
Wish I knew on the candy thermometer where should be. That guessing 5 minutes after hard boil is hard to determine.

This was my third attempt making fudge. I'm not great in the kitchen. FINALLY, SUCCESS!! They tastes amazing and easy to make! Make sure you follow the directions, exactly!! This is the fudge you and your family will request every year!!
My family’s go to fudge recipe!
Cut back on the sugar by 3/4 cup, don’t need to boil 5 minutes 3 does the trick. I always use 1 stick of butter
I first made this with my mother back in the 70's. She's been gone 12 years now but I still use it as my go-to fudge recipe. SO SIMPLE YET SO TASTY!!

Follow the recipe to a “T” and it’s perfect fudge! For those that said the time was wrong, that was not my experience. If you wait until the butter/sugar mixture comes to a full rolling boil and cook exactly 5 minutes, remove from heat and complete recipe as stated, creamy perfection!!

I was so disappointed. I followed the instructions exactly, I melted the butter, sugar and evaporated milk together and then brought it to a rolling boil for five minutes stirring constantly then took it off the heat to add the chocolate etc. and it seized up! If only I had read other recipes before I started I would’ve known not to cook it at a rolling boil for five minutes but rather until it reached 234 degrees or approximately 4 minutes, although I believe temperature is key! Oh, and the actual original Kraft recipe said you can use margarine or butter.
Wonderful
This recipe just WORKS. I have it taped on the inside of a cupboard door so I make it summer or winter. I ALWAYS make a double batch, and now people ask for it!

Have used this recipe for over 30 yrs ! * I use 1/2 Semi Sweet chips and 1/2 Milk chocolate chips * I use butter * I put the marshmallow cream in a low double boiler (loosen the lid)while the sugar mixture boils so as to get more of it out of the jar easier * Most important - invest in a Candy Thermometer - so worth it !

I have been making this every year for about 40 years. I always use butter. I never grease the pan. It never sticks to my glass pans. I make about 9 lbs. I bring it to a full rolling boil for 5 minutes which always works. My family loves it and it is a tradition for me to make it and I usually run out of it. My family knows to return the tins so I can fill them up next year.
Great recipe but please use butter. SO much better.

This is the all time best recipe for fudge. It is a four generation favorite in our family!! I'm 75 years old and this is the recipe my mother made. I have passed the recipe to my girls and now they have passed it to their It brings back Christmas memories to me every year. I'm so glad it is still around, please make it your family favorite too!!

I made this fudge for the first time in my Home Economics class. That was 46 years ago. I have been making it ever since. After gifting it to aunts & uncles once, the tradition began. It is super easy & oh so good!

I have made this fudge for years. It is the best! But don’t be afraid to change it up a bit. Try making vanilla/pecan (my personal favorite), green mint with crushed candy cane on top, or even pistachio with candied cherries mixed in with the nuts. This recipe is a great starter for your sweet tooth imagination.
This is the best fudge recipe. It tastes great every time. Smooth!
Best recipe for fudge
Made this recipe since childhood. Always turns out great. Can be made with butterscotch chips as well. Marchino Cherries can be quartered and added to the chocolate variety.

I have used this recipe for years. I use the microwave to make it. You can also use peanut butter chips instead of chocolate and it comes out the same. It is great. I make a lot of this at Christmas time. Any flavored chips work for the fudge. Let your imagination go wild.

I've been making this recipe for years, since my children were little, and now I have grandchildren. My granddaughter and I made it today. I've made it with semisweet chocolate morsels, milk chocolate morsels and no nuts sometimes. It is perfect if you follow the recipe exactly.
It was easy and simple. I did make some changes with the sugar.
I have been making this fudge for years and do exactly what it says and it turns out every time!! Ruth
Using this recipe for years. Use a candy thermometer.
This is my go to recipe. Turns out perfect and creamy every time.

Have used this recipe for years, but the last couple of times it didn't turn out well. I used Jet-Puffed Marshmallow cream both times. When I want to put it in the pan, there was a liquid laying on the top that was kind of clear. No idea what it was. The fudge turned out a little grainy as well. The only ingredient I used that was different was the Jet-Puffed.
You *Have To" bring the recipe to 234°F or fuge will not set. Big fail of the recipe
Went step by step on the recipe. But it came out super hard!
After I added the chocolate, the oil starts to separate from the mixture. This recipe is very difficult to make. I won't make it again.
So easy and delicious!
Used this recipe for 40 years. I have never used 3 cups sugar- only 2 cups. Fudge sets up fine. It is not as sweet, but creamier!

If you start a 5 minute timer as soon as you see a SLIGHT boil you will get soft, melt in your mouth fudge. If you wait for the full raging boil and time 5 minutes you will get a sift hard fudge that crumbles. For the soft fudge, score lightly on top with a table knife when hot.
Do not just boil for 5 minutes. If you follow this recipe you will end up with syrup. Use a candy thermometer or it will not set.

Excellent and easy as always! The only problem I've ever had is humidity in Texas. Yes, its December in Texas, Christmas day will be sunny and 82 with ridiculous humidity!
But, fudge is perfect!

Lovely to swirl the marshmallows (I decided to listen to comments, and use marshmallows rather than the creme), so they do not melt completely. Tossed a handful of Christmas color (red & green) mini m&ms on top, to be festive. Yum!

This is a very good, easy recipe. You must follow the cooking instructions closely though. You can make it with less sugar and butter via the stovetop recipe. You can’t if you microwave it, though- at least not cutting back on the butter. I only use 1/2 cup of butter on the stove and about 2 cups of sugar. I tried this in the microwave and I got a dry, crumbly mess. I quickly added in the other 1/4 cup of butter, melted it and stirred like a maniac, and it came out… passable. I made a peanut butter version prior to this, by using 1 cup of crunchy peanut butter and not altering the butter, and it it was just fine. But then- I just made 2 batches of the normal chocolate chip kind, following the instructions exactly, and it was a dry crumbly mess, which turned into dry topped, crackled baked brownie looking stuff, with butter pooling on top when I put it into the pans. No more microwave cooking. I’m going back to the original stove top method that I e used for 38 yrs, since I was in middle school. And- making it in a 13x 9 pan makes thin, less appetizing fudge anyway. The thick fudge shown in the picture was either a double recipe, or made in an 8-9” square pan.
The ingredient list is misleading for beginners, for the evaporated milk it's not the whole can which they make it look like in bold for a 12 fl oz can, ruined my fudge realizing its only 2/3 a cup

Love this recipe! I do wish someone would have pointed out that it says it wields 117 servings. To be honest I don’t know if this is a typo or the amount of butter and sugar could legitimately feed 117 people. That being said we doubled the recipe!
The original recipe calls for half as much evaporated milk!!! Wish I would have read the reviews before making chocolate soup
So easy to make and delicious. I will definitely save this in my Favorite recipes
Just like Grandma's!
I boil mine for 1/2-1 minute longer to make a darker fudge.

I'd give it nearly 5 stars (4.5-4.75). Made as written except poured into a 11" x 11" pan as I wanted larger fudge chunks. I can foresee creating more flavors by changing the nuts, extract, addition of fruits, liqueurs, etc. I will be making this again and testing new flavors. Such a quick and easy recipe to give as a gift. Who doesn't love fudge?
I used Reese's peanut butter chips and I also added Heath toffee bits and walnuts. So good. Switched the vanilla out for almond.

My parents did this receipt since I can remember My father always use the timing of five minutes when I started making it myself sometimes it would come out right sometimes not always right with a candy thermometer try this though instead of the semi sweet morsels add 1 cup of peanut butter preferably creamy peanut butter exact same recipe but exchange the chips for the Peanut butter it is the best peanut butter fudge you will get amywhere

I have made the fantasy fudge for years on the stove top and always perfect. Tried the microwave method & after adding chocolate chips it was very grainy, mixed in fluff & vanilla still rather sugary & oily on top from the butter I’d assume. I would not recommend microwave method .

Before my boys left for college, I stumbled across the back of Marshmallow Crème the recipe for “Microwave Fudge”! I was ecstatic bc my Mom had attempted fudge my entire life, unsuccessfully I might add. So to find a microwave Recipe was a dream come true. No one will ever know the difference bc it taste exactly like fudge fussed over if not done PRECISELY correct, you had a mess. Thank you for still having the recipe of your website bc I lost mine a few years ago! Merry Christmas 
Robin (Roll Tide)

I made this twice. The first batch was so grainy I thought the sugar mixture must have been to hot when I added the chocolate. In the second batch, I let it cool a bit before adding the chocolate, but it was still grainy. Years ago I used to make this and it was great. I used Girardelli dark chocolate chips--wonder if that was the problem
Just poured it into pan. My grandson loved the “scrapings”.
As always, perfecto!
Easy to make. I cut the sugar in half.
I have been making this fudge every year for at least 45 years. It is sooooo good every time. It never fails!!!

Liked the recipe especially since there is no half hour of hard hand beating. It’s funny so many people saying to boil to 234F as 5 minutes won’t work as mine reached 234 in a little UNDER 5 minutes of boiling. So I’d say some may be making too much of just going by temperature, seems either will work.
Creamy, chocolate awesomeness!

I have been making this exact fudge since the 1970's for our first Air Force Squadron party! It is the best! Now my granddaughter requests that I must arrive at every Christmas with Nanny's fudge! You must use the best ingredients- only butter and real vanilla. I don't add nuts as a family preference. We also cut it into small pieces as it's very rich-Enjoy!

To make it a 5 star add Several improvements: use butter, add a little salt, garnish with sea salt. Orange zest is great with this. Just stir it in. Use a candy thermometer for perfect fudge every time.
Yummy! Just as I remembered it!
Would not set at all. And tastes more like an old tootsie roll than fudge!
I have been making this fudge exactly like this for more than 30 years. Have already made 4 batches for friends and family. I highly recommend this original recipe.
I love this fudge. I follow the recipe except for the amount of sugar. I only use 2 C. I find it is sweet enough and creamier.
Been making this for years, but instead of chocolate chips, I use peanut butter and maple flavoring. Really good.
More like 2 !/2 stars. Tastes good. But set up so quick couldn't stir and mix everything.

This is the recipe my mom used to make. I change it up a bit by adding a cup or so of peanut butter which, to me, makes it taste less sweet. I also mix the sugar, milk and butter on high heat (electric) until the first bubble starts and then turn the temperature down to medium. It takes less time to get to the boiling point this way, but constant stirring is a must at all times.
Cost is low, cooking is simple, results were delicious.
Awesome recipe came out perfect! I used half chocolate cups and half white morsels. Thank you for sharing!

I made the recipe exactly as stated above for my first batch of fudge. It turned out great! The second time I substituted the white sugar with the same quantity of brown sugar; I used butterscotch chips instead of chocolate and instead of vanilla extract I used maple extract. The fudge turned out much smoother and creamier than the chocolate fudge. They tasted like butterscotch with a hint of maple. Very yummy!
This is my favorite fudge recipe. All others pale in comparison. I substitute peanut butter chips for chocolate chips, and it tastes like the inside of a Reeses Peanut Butter Cup.
My absolute favorite!!

I very carefully followed the recipe - the microwave version .I took extra precaution to follow it exactly because I did not want to waste my time or money if it failed. Well, I Just threw out the whole thing - it was so bad! I am really not happy! I reviewed the recipe and could not find what I did wrong. The microwave recipe did not mention the power of the microwave used ( 1000 watt, 1500 watt?). It also didn't say it it should be stirred at intervals during the 5 1/2 minute cooking time. It seems these are the only 2 areas that could have gone gwrong. Silly me for following this recipe! Next time I'll pick a recipe that's complete with all pertinent information on a different site.
I found it to be gritty or grainy. Also the other fluff fudge recipes called for salt.

We’ve used this recipe as long as I can remember, although we don’t mix the marshmallow cream in while it’s on the heat; we always whip it in right after taking it off the stove; it gives beautiful little white swirls throughout the fudge. This year, I’m going to try adding flavor extract(s) to the marshmallow cream before swirling it in. 
I’m doing Bailey’s Irish Cream first, which just sounds delish!
Delicious!!
I made this with 9 oz. of Nestle espresso chips and about 3/4 cup of semi-sweet chips. It is amazing!
Good basic recipe. Super easy! Be sure and add walnuts, or as I did, roasted pecans (by that peanut shaped guy), for the salt. This would be good to recipe to do with the kiddos.

This is a good recipe but don’t listen to those telling you to cook it for 10 minutes. That ruined my fudge. It was over cooked and crumbly. When it starts getting dry, it goes dry quickly. Just follow the recipe here. The Kraft recipe tells you to put these same ingredients in a 9x9 pan. Don’t. Put it in a 9x13 as listed in recipe above.

I've been making this recipe for 30 plus years. I've been switching out the chocolate chips and changing them with different flavors for something different. It works. You can even add a 12 ounce jar of peanut butter and it works. I always use the microwave directions, which are easier for me. Add the vanilla. This is my favorite candy.

Never disappoints! My mom wasn't a great cook, but this always worked for her. My tips: Use a heavy bottomed pan. A cheap one will burn. 
Have everything laid out before you start. Once this starts, you cannot walk away. Stir constantly, don't stop stirring! Watch your heat--not too hot or too low. Sets up better in the fridge. Keep it cold.
I loved it turned out vreat

I greatly appreciated comments, I decided to use a thermometer AND time the boil at 5 min, as soon as it reaches a rolling boil - when it stays boiling when you are stirring. It took a little more than 5 min, probably 30 seconds more. I used 4 ounces dark chocolate, in place of semi sweet. 4 stars only because I haven't tasted it yet! Very easy to follow for a first timer.

I'm obsessed with chocolate and peanut butter, so I used this recipe to make the bottom layer of a layered chocolate-peanut butter fudge (using Grandma's Creamy Peanut Butter Fudge recipe for the top layer.) It turned out fantastic! I left out the walnuts because I was already doing a peanut butter layer and because my daughter is allergic to tree nuts. I will definitely use this recipe again, both for the layered fudge and probably on its own.
The taste was great, but it never set up. If you want to eat it with a spoon then it's great. I will go back to my old recipe.
Made the fudge according to the recipe. It turned out great. Super moist.
I make this fudge every year at Christmas. The only thing I do differently is leave out the walnuts because we don't care for nuts in our fudge. It is delicious and so easy to make!
The cooking time for microwave was way too long. I ruined the first batch! I cooked the second batch five minutes and it was great
The recipe on the jar Now is wrong. It comes out like frosting instead. I'll use this one. I made some yesterday and it's not solid like it should be. Don't use the new recipe on the jar. Use this.
This recipe has always been the one I use, I love black walnuts to mine.
Just what I was looking for! Love this website.

This is the same recipe my grandmother had in her personal cookbook she started in the 60s, except hers is doubled. It also says boil for 5 mins. She suggests in her notes to use peanut butter chips instead of chocolate which was always my favorite. She’s has a second recipe labeled “Best Fantasy Fudge” which calls for 4c sug, 1 can milk, 1/4lbs Oleo (marg.) 12oz chips, 1 pt marsh cream, 2c nuts, and 1 lg Hershey bar (prepared the same way).

My Mother Started Making Fantasy Fudge 55+ Years Ago. She Always Used Real Butter, NEVER margarine, Made a Creamier Less Oily Fudge. Used the Recipe on the Marshmallow Cream Jar. She Used the Same Recipe and Made Butterscotch Fudge, Peanut Butter Fudge, Chocolate Peanut Butter Fudge. She Made the Best Fudge ... Fond Memories
This is the first time I’ve ever made fudge...I made it for Mother’s Day and had to hide the few leftover pieces. I don’t believe I’ve ever bought fudge from a store that is better than this recipe.
